user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.2 is: Functions shall not call themselves, either directly or indirectly.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_irq_register_controller:
```c
int metal_irq_register_controller(struct metal_irq_controller *cntr)
{
	int irq_base;
	struct metal_list *node;

	if (cntr == NULL) {
		return -EINVAL;
	}
	metal_list_for_each(&irq_cntrs, node) {
		if (node == &cntr->node) {
			return 0;
		}
	}

	/*
	 * Allocate IRQ numbers which are not yet used by any IRQ
	 * controllers.
	 */
	irq_base = metal_irq_allocate(cntr->irq_base, cntr->irq_num);
	if (irq_base == METAL_IRQ_ANY) {
		return -EINVAL;
	}
	cntr->irq_base = irq_base;

	metal_list_add_tail(&irq_cntrs, &cntr->node);
	return 0;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function metal_irq_register_controller:
static int metal_irq_allocate(int irq_base, int irq_num)
{
	struct metal_list *node;
	struct metal_irq_controller *cntr;
	int irq_tocheck = irq_base, irq_end_tocheck;

	if (irq_num == 0) {
		return METAL_IRQ_ANY;
	}
	if (irq_tocheck == METAL_IRQ_ANY) {
		irq_tocheck = 0;
	}
	irq_end_tocheck = irq_tocheck + irq_num;

	metal_list_for_each(&irq_cntrs, node) {
		int cntr_irq_base, cntr_irq_end;

		cntr = metal_container_of(node,
					  struct metal_irq_controller, node);
		cntr_irq_base = cntr->irq_base;
		cntr_irq_end = cntr_irq_base + cntr->irq_num;
		if (irq_tocheck < cntr_irq_end &&
		    irq_end_tocheck > cntr_irq_base) {
			if (irq_base != METAL_IRQ_ANY) {
				/* IRQ has been allocated */
				return METAL_IRQ_ANY;
			}
			irq_tocheck = cntr_irq_end;
			irq_end_tocheck = irq_tocheck + irq_num;
		}
	}
	return irq_tocheck;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I found no direct or indirect calls from metal_irq_register_controller back to itself. Analysis of the provided code paths: 
- metal_irq_register_controller calls only metal_list_for_each (a list-iteration macro), metal_irq_allocate, and metal_list_add_tail. None of these, as shown, invoke metal_irq_register_controller.
- metal_irq_allocate (provided) iterates the same list and uses metal_container_of; it does not call metal_irq_register_controller or any other function that could call it.
- The fields accessed on struct metal_irq_controller (irq_base, irq_num, node) are data members, not function pointers, so there is no callback-based indirect recursion in the shown code.
- The typical implementations of metal_list_for_each, metal_list_add_tail, and metal_container_of are macros for pointer manipulation and do not perform function calls; their provided usage shows only list traversal and insertion.

Given the supplied code, there is no evidence of direct or indirect recursion related to Rule 17.2, so no code fragments require further investigation for recursion. If implementations of metal_list_for_each, metal_list_add_tail, or other unshown helpers contain function calls or invoke callbacks, those definitions should be reviewed, but they were not provided and are unlikely to introduce recursion based on typical implementations.
